webTitle: Eurozone crisis: Greece meets with Troika over next aid payment - live

fields.standfirst:
• Closing summary
• Vitor Gaspar resigns
• Analysis: Troika talks begin in Athens
• Jobless rate hits 12.1% in May - details from 10am
• Signs of stabilisation in Italy and Spain
fields.body:
6.11pm BST

Closing summary

Time to wrap up for the day. Here's a brief closing summary.

• Greece's government has begun a new round of crucial talks with officials fom its lenders. At issue, whether to advance the country's next aid tranche, worth around €8bn. Insiders warned tonight that tension between the two sides is high, as the Troika probes whether Greece has made enough progress cutting civil service staff levels, and selling state assets.

Latest analysis from Helena Smith in Athens is here:

• Portugal's finance minister has resigned. Vitor Gaspar blamed falling public support for the country's austerity programme, and warned that the Lisbon government faced a difficult future (see 5.03pm onwards).

• Eurozone unemployment levels hit new record highs, with the jobless rate rising to 12.1%. The latest figures from Eurostat showed that Spain, Greece and Portugal still have the highest unemployment rates, particularly for young people, while Cyprus's labour market has deteriorated sharply (see 10.14am onwards).

• The latest factory data offered some respite for southern Europe. Spain and Italy both posted better-than expected manufacturing PMI figures (see 8.39am onwards.

However Germany and China (see 7.45am)'s PMI data missed forecasts, while the US version (see 3.06pm) showed a weakening labour market.

• In the UK, Mark Carney took control at the Bank of England. There's video of Carney's first day here (3.22pm), and details of his trip on the Underground here (11.33am).

I"ll be back tomorrow. Until then, thanks and goodnight.

5.52pm BST

Analysis on the latest Greek bailout talks

With those crunch talks between the Greek finance ministry and the Troika underway, our Athens correspondent Helena Smith reports that the situation is as tense as ever.

She also flags up that Greec is very likely to only receive its next aid tranche in slices, rather than one lump sum.

Here's Helena's analysls:

Even when they look good, Greece’s relations with the international creditors keeping its debt-stricken economy afloat are rarely without tension.

Both sides regard the other with thinly disguised suspicion. Since troika officials from the EU, ECB and IMF began visiting Athens to pour over the nation’s financial book-keeping, inspection tours have been fraught with friction in a game that, more often than not, resembles a match of constant goal-post moving than one adhered to with fixed rules.

Today’s visit is no different. While ties have generally improved in the year since the smooth-talking technocrat Yiannis Stournaras was elevated to the post of finance minister, this afternoon’s discussions are genuinely expected to be “very tough.”

The troika has made clear that it will only disburse aid when, and if, specific reforms are taken. The likelihood of the country’s super tranche – €8.1bn in aid – being dispatched in installments is now a given.

“It’s going to make for a very heavy climate but they have made it very clear that that is what they are going to do,” said one insider. “Every time we announce a measure, we’ll get an installment. That is the premise they are working on.”

Measures now mean pubic sector dismissals – the red line no Greek government has wanted to cross since the outbreak of the debt crisis in late 2009. The troika wants 15,000 civil servants cut from the payroll in 2015. The government missed yesterday’s deadline of placing some 12,500 in a mobility scheme and the Administrative Reform Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis said he would ask for a two-month extension when he met troika mission heads at 7:30pm (local time) (5.30pm BST) tonight.

This is unlikely to go down well. Before the fraca over the closure of state broadcaster ERT – one that the government will surely use to highlight the sensitivity of public sector sackings -- troika officials were demanding names and numbers and are going to be reluctant to move the goal posts again. If they do, there will have to be concessions elsewhere – most likely in the reining in of public spending at Greece’s main healthcare provider, EOPYY.

The projected financing gap of €4bn by the second half of 2014 (when Greece’s second bailout programme is due to end) has added to the black mood.

So has the slow pace of privatisations with officials on both sides now openly recognising the impossibility of raising €2.6bn through the sale of state assets by the end of the year. The atmosphere will worsen considerably if the €700m euro sale of the state lottery company OPAP also falls through. Speculation of this happening has exacerbated tensions with creditors in recent days. Its collapse would automatically increase the need for further cuts to put the bailout programme on track.

The health ministry, with EOPYY at the fore, is likely to be called on to carry most of the burden of covering the looming budget gap. The new health minister, Adonis Georgiades, was appointed to the post precisely because he has no ties with the medical community thus making it easier for him to wield the axe. On Sunday evening he lived up to expectation promising he will close hospitals to meet targets “if necessary”.

It will be the beginning of the new measures the government is so vehemently insisting it will not take when everything suggests that new measures are in the offing.

Updated at 6.16pm BST

5.42pm BST

Reuters is now reporting that Vitor Gaspar blamed his resignation on eroding public support for Portugal's austerity programme, and the court ruling earlier this year that blocked planned cuts to payments for pensioners and public workers.

The outgoing finance minister also warned that the "risks and challenges ahead are enormous", and admitted his credibility had been damaged by Portugal's struggle to hit its deficit targets.

5.19pm BST

Gaspar out, Albuquerque in

It's official -- the Portuguese president has confirmed that Vitor Gaspar has stepped down as finance minister, to be replaced by treasury secretary Maria Luis de Albuquerque.

Here's the statement from the presidency .

And here's a rough translation:

Pursuant to paragraph h) of Article 133 of the Constitution, the President accepted the proposal made by the Prime Minister, to dismiss, at his request, the Minister of State and Finance, Prof.. Dr. Vítor Gaspar Louçã Rabaça.

The President accepted the proposal made by the Prime Minister, the appointment of Dr. Luis Maria Casanova Morgado Dias de Albuquerque to the same office.

The inauguration of the new member of the Government shall take place tomorrow, Tuesday, July 2, at 17:00 in the Palace of Belém.

Updated at 5.33pm BST

5.09pm BST

Portuguese finance minister quits

Reuters is now reporting that the Portuguese prime minister has accepted the resignation of Vitor Gaspar as finance minister (so the rumours were true....)

He's been replaced by Maria Luis Albuquerque, previously the Treasury secretary.

5.03pm BST

Portugal's finance minister, Vítor Gaspar, may be throwing in the towel, with local media reporting tonight that he is considering tendering his resignation.

There's nothing official, so treat with all caution.

Gaspar has ploughed a tough furrow in Portugal, trying to implement spending cuts and tax rises demanded by the Troika, in the face of public anger.

Peter Spiegel of the FT reports that Gaspar would be missed in Brussels:

4.57pm BST

European markets close

Europe's stock markets have begun the second half of 2013 with solid gains, led by Spain, Italy and the UK – where the FTSE 100 closed up 92 points.

All three countries posted better-than-expected manufacturing data this morning, and this seems to have fed through to traders.

Here's the closing prices:

Steve Collins, global head of dealing at London & Capital Asset Management, confirmed that the decent manufacturing data had dampened concerns over the situation in Greece.

4.41pm BST

Japonica's Greek debt offer takes a twist

Another curious story involving Greece today: Japonica, a little-known US investment firm, has reduced the price at which it is prepared to buy Greek debt, but is keen to snaffle even more of the stuff.

Japonica, of Rhode Island, caused a stir last month when it first proposed buying €2.9bn of Greek debt from existing creditors at 45% of its face value.

Today, though, the company announced it will only pay 40 euro cents in the €1. It blamed recent declines in the value of Greek debt, uncertainty over whether it will get its aid tranche, and tension within its government.

Or in Japonica's words, the threat of:

prospective debt haircuts, Greece government intracoalition relations, reports of a potential €3bn to €4bn funding gap, privatization revenue shortfalls, reports of a €1.2bn health-care-cost funding gap, the closure [of state broadcaster ERT], and concerns regarding quarter-end portfolio performance markings for such illiquid securities.

If Greece is in such a mess, you'd think Japonica would keep away. But the firm says it hasn't lost its appetite for Greek debt -- and is now prepared to buy €4bn-worth of bonds.

The offer perplexed many in the City, and it's not clear whether anyone's taken up the offer. Greek debt had strengthened steadily since the drama of its two elections in 2012 - so anyone who bought bonds then is sitting on healthy profits. As Bloomberg argues here, they may not want to sell out to Japonica just yet....

Updated at 4.46pm BST

4.24pm BST

Greece to pay bond holdout, but clamp down on fare dodging

Speaking of Greece, its government appears poised to pay €540m to a 'holdout' investor who didn't take part in last year's debt restructuring.

The bond, which was issued under Swiss law, matures on Friday. Its owner refused to swap the debt for new, longer-maturity securities in March 2012. And Athens appears to have decided it's better to pay the debt off than refuse to honour it and provoke a legal battle.

But while Greece seemingly has the money to settle with holdout creditors, it is still gunning for public services. Health minister Adonis Georgiadis caused alarm over the weekend by saying he was prepared to shut hospitals if it would drive up efficiency and cut costs.

And bus drivers are up in arms over a plan to make passengers get on through the front doors, near their cabin, in an effort to stop fare-dodging.

3.51pm BST

The talks between Troika officials and Greek finance minister Yannis Stournaras over the country's bailout programme, and whether Athens should get its next aid tranche worth €8bn, are underway.

Here's a photo of European Commission director Matthias Mors, centre, arriving for the meeting this afternoon:

With government insiders already warning that the talks will be tough (see 2.12pm onwards) we could be in for a nervy few days....

3.22pm BST

Video: Bank of England Mark Carney gets down to work

Your chance to watch a rather powerful central banker walk down a corridor, open a door, and address the massed ranks of the Bank of England's senior staff:

Carney appeared to be enjoying the attention, and didn't waste any time telling staff that he'd been there since 7am*.

* - not bad for a newcomer.

Reminder: I rounded up some of the reams of advice sent Carney's way at 1.10pm

Updated at 3.28pm BST

3.12pm BST

The news that hiring across America's manufacturing sector weakened last month (see 3.06pm) drove shares in London and Wall Street even higher (FTSE 100 now up 96 points, Dow up 166 points). Looks like we're back to bad news being good news, if it keeps the ultra-loose monetary policy in place....

3.06pm BST

US ISM data released

The ISM survey of America's manufacturing sector is out (not to be confused with the Markit version released earlier), and it's a mixed picture.

The headline figures has improved, rising to 50.9 (denoting growth), following last month's 49.0 (which showed a contraction).

However, the 'employment index' part of the survey fell below the 50-point mark for the first time since September 2009, indicating a drop in hiring.

And with the Federal Reserve targeting the labour market as well as headline GDP, that may also encourage central bankers to hold off tapering their bond-buying programmes....

2.53pm BST

Markets begin July with a rally

The better-than-expected manufacturing data from Italy and Spain (hinting at eurozone recovery), and the weaker-than-expected manufacturing data from America (hinting at a slower end to the US stimulus package) have helped to push shares up today.

Wall Street has opened higher, while in London the blue-chip Footsie is up 82 points, mirroring similar gains across Europe.

• Dow Jones: up 114 points at 15025, +0.78%

• FTSE 100: up 82 points at 6297, + 1.3%

• German DAX: up 40 points at 799, + 0.5%

• French CAC: up 30 points at 3769, +0.8%

• Spanish IBEX: up 140 points at 7903, +1.8%

• Italian FTSE MIB: up 261 point at 15501, +1.7%

2.27pm BST

Back to economic data, and the first of two readings of the US manufacturing sector has been released, and is weaker than expected.

Markit's PMI survey of America's factory sector last month came in at 51.9, which is the slowest pace of expansion in eight months.

The data did show a small rise in business conditions, and output growth, but it suggests the US economy isn't recovering as fast as some analysts had hoped. And that may mean the Federal Reserve doesn't slow its stimulus package so quicky.

Chris Williamson, Markit's chief economist, warned that:

Manufacturing clearly down-shifted a gear between the first and second quarters, and is at risk of losing further momentum as we head into the second half of the year

We get the rival ISM manufacturing data at 3pm BST.

In the meantime, European shares are pushing higher - with the FTSE 100 up over 1%. Full round-up to follow

Updated at 2.54pm BST

2.21pm BST

As flagged up this morning, one of the key issues on the table in Greece is the planned dismissal of 15,000 civil servants by the end of 2014 and the placing of another 12,500 in a mobility scheme.

Kathimerini has more details on this afternoon's talks between Greece and the Troika, pointing out that the meetings will run into tomorrow....

The troika is to begin its meetings at the Finance Ministry on Monday afternoon at 5 pm (3pm BST). They are due to meet new Administrative Reform Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis at 7.30p.m [5.30pm BST].

Mitsotakis is expected to ask for more time to complete the mobility scheme. The inspectors will then visit the Labor Ministry on Tuesday morning.

2.12pm BST

Greece heads into showdown with Troika

Over in Greece, we're still expecting talks between the government and officials from its lenders to resume this afternoon, around 3pm BST.

As outlined this morning (8.23am) the Troika are back in town to see how the Greek government measures up against its bailout targets. And the mood music from Athens isn't encouraging, with one finance ministry official describing the negotiations between Greece and the troika as "truly difficult".

A couple of newswires are also quoting unnamed eurozone officials warning that Greece hasn't yet done enough to qualify for its next aid tranche:

Updated at 2.16pm BST

1.33pm BST

Spanish and Italian bonds rally

The improvements in Italy and Spain's manufacturing sectors (see 8.39am onwards) have been welcomed in the City, while the latest eurozone unemployment gloom (10.14am) has been shrugged off.

Spanish and Italian government bonds have strengthened in value, pushing their borrowing costs down.

The yield (interest rate) on a Spanish 10-year sovereign bond has now fallen to 4.628%, down from 4.71% on Friday night. The Italian equivalent dropped to 4.49% (from 4.53%).

Both countries' bonds had fallen in value since the US Federal Reserve laid out how to slow, and stop its stimulus package amost two weeks ago. With several Fed officials having made soothing noises since, traders may reckon there's less to worry about - and that peripheral eurozone debt looks safer again...

1.10pm BST

A couple more photos of Mark Carney's first morning at the Bank of England:

The new governor hits the ground running with his first meeting of the monetary policy committee this week (where interest rates and quantitative easing programmes are set). But what should his priorities be?

Saturday's Guardian leader column urged Carney to get to grips with Britain's banks, and use every lever he can find to drive growth:

The new governor has already hinted that he would like a more flexible inflation target (perhaps keeping CPI to 2% over three not two years); he should go further and push for a Federal Reserve-style remit that sets off moderate inflation against the need for jobs (and wage) growth.

Now is also the time to use QE, that is public money, to direct investment into key sectors (such as green energy) and under-industrialised regions. Mr Carney is famously smooth, but if he does not start his tenure by picking a few important fights, it will be a disappointing omen.

While five experts have given the Observer their views on the challenges facing Carney -- from weaning Britain off ultra-loose monetary policy to improving the Bank's own credibilty. Here's the details: A little advice, Mr Carney … your credibility will be crucial

While the British Chamber of Commerce has called for more help for small firms.

And you can vote here on whether Carney will do better than Sir Mervyn King.

12.30pm BST

Cyprus completes bond-swap

Over in Cyprus, the finance ministry reports that it has completed a bond-swap with investors, fulfilling another condition of its bailout deal:

From the Reuters terminal:

Cyprus said on Monday it had completed the exchange of €1bn in maturing domestic government debt for new longer-term government paper as part of its financial adjustment programme.

Five types of bonds with maturities ranging from six to 10 years were issued, offering the same coupons as the government bonds they replaced, term sheets issued by the finance ministry said.

This swap helps Cyprus as it reduces the amount of sovereign debt it must repay during the lifespan of its bailout programme. But the exchange also saw its credit rating cut to selective default by S&P last Friday (as the new terms are less favourable)

11.33am BST

Back to London, and my colleague Jennifer Rankin has established that Mark Carney braved the Underground on his first day at the Bank of England this morning.

She writes that governor Carney was spotted by at least one City worker, who was able to point him in the right direction:

The Canadian central banker is tipped to shake up the 319-year old institution, which has been criticised by politicians for insularity and group-think and not enough vigilance in the runup to the financial crisis.

This change of style also starts – today at least – with a journey on the central line, stuffy on a midsummer morning, although he did at least get a seat.

"It is nice to see someone being suitably parsimonious," said Justin Urquhart Stewart, managing director of Seven Investment Management, who spotted Carney on the tube.

"I've established he definitely wasn't George Clooney," he said. "I wished him good luck." Urquhart Stewart also advised Carney on the best exit to take at Bank underground station.

If only all Carney's dilemmas were so easily solved....

More here: Mark Carney takes tube to office on first day as Bank of England governor

Updated at 11.34am BST

11.18am BST

Euro unemployment data - early reaction

City analysts believe the eurozone unemployment rate will keep rising in the months ahead, after hitting 12.1% in May (see 10.14am onwards for details).

Martin van Vliet of ING explains:

The country breakdown showed that the increase in unemployment was broadly-based, with Cyprus again standing out negatively (16.3% versus 15.8% previously) but Germany and Austria bucking the trend of increased unemployment.

Looking ahead, an end to the Eurozone labour market downturn is not yet imminent. Indeed, the employment expectations indices from the European Commission’s business survey are still at levels consistent with further increases in unemployment.

However, with the recession across the Eurozone petering out, the peak in unemployment should not be too far away either.

While Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight has predicted that the rate will hit 12.5% by the end of this year, despite today's encouraging manufacturing PMIs (see 9.27am).

Archer writes:

A general turnaround in Eurozone labour markets still looks some way off so unemployment seems set to rise appreciably further. The situation will likely vary markedly between countries.

While, Eurozone GDP could have finally stopped contracting in the second quarter after a record six quarters of decline, overall economic activity is likely to remain too weak through 2013, and very possibly during the early months of 2014, to prevent unemployment from rising further.

10.57am BST

Euro inflation up

The cost of living in the eurozone picked up late last month, but at 1.6% the consumer prices index remained low in historical terms.

Eurostat said the increase in the CPI, from 1.4% last month, was due to increased costs of food, alcohol and tobacco, energy, and services.

The European Central Bank's aim is to keep inflation close to, but below, 2%, so today's reading shouldn't alarm policymakers, and might even calm fears of deflation.

Although, as Mario Draghi explained at his most recent press conference on June 6:

The fact that inflation is low is not, by itself, bad; with low inflation, you can buy more stuff.

Nice to see an economist cutting through the jargon....

10.47am BST

Youth unemployment - the details

Last week, European leaders were proudly announcing that they'd put €8bn aside to fight youth unemployment.

Today's data confirms that the problem is particularly severe in southern Europe. Greece is suffering a youth unemployment rate of 59.2%, followed by Spain with 56.5% and Portugal with 42.1%.

Northern European countries are in much better shape, particularly Germany (7.6%), Austria (8.7%) and the Netherlands (10.6%).

Eurostat has calculated that there are 3.531m young people out of work in the eurozone, up by 60,000 on a year ago, and 5.5m across the Euopean Union.

The only upside? Eurostat has revised its historical data down, so that the youth jobless rate is 23.8% across the eurozone (not the 24.4% estimated last month).

10.34am BST

EU jobless rate flat

And while the eurozone jobless rate hit a new record high, the rate in the European Union was flat in May, at 10.9%.

That's because the proportion of people out of work in some EU countries outside the euro fell, including Sweden (from 8.3% to 7.9), and Denmark (from 5.4% to 5.3%).

10.28am BST

Eurozone unemployment, the details

Seventeen members of the eurozone have higher unemployment rates than a year ago, and 10 have lower rates -- which pushed the jobless rate up to today's 12.1% in May.

Once again, the lowest unemployment rates were recorded in Austria (4.7%), Germany (5.3%) and Luxembourg (5.7%), and the highest in Spain (26.9%) and Greece (26.8% in March 2013).

Cyprus, which was dragged into a bailout crisis earlier this month, suffered the biggest annual rise - from 11.4% in May 2012 to 16.3% this year.

Greece's jobless rate rose from 22.2% to 26.8% over the last year.

And Slovenia, which is fighting to avoid taking a bailout, has seen its jobless rate increase from 8.6% a year ago to 11.2% today.

The largest decreases were observed in Latvia, Estonia and
Lithuania.

10.14am BST

Eurozone unemployment hits new record hgih

The unemployment rate across the eurozone hit record levels in May, as the recession continued to hurt workers across the region.

Eurostat reported that the jobless rate across the eurozone was 12.1% in May, up from 12.0% in April. It was driven by increased unemployment rates in countries at the heart of the crisis, including Spain, Italy, and Ireland.

The number of people out of work across the eurozone rose by 67,000, and picked up by 16,000 in the wider European Union.

And young people continued to find themselves in the front line of the jobless crisis -- the youth unemployment rate was 23.0% in the EU27 and 23.8% in the euro area, up from 22.8% and 23.0% respectively a year ago.

There are now 26.405m unemployed men and women in the EU27, of whom 19.222 million were in the euro area.

The only reason for optimism is that Eurostat has revised down its earlier data slightly-- it had previously estimated the eurozone jobless rate at 12.2% in May. That's small comfort, though.

Details and reaction to follow....

Updated at 11.29am BST

10.00am BST

Jeremy Cook of World First says the City was cheered by the news that Britain's manufacturing sector enjoyed its best month in two years (see 9.41am)

Sterling and gilts are higher after the announcement which is a nice welcoming present for the new Bank of England Governor, Mark Carney, on his first day in the job…”

The new orders component which tends to suggest that demand should be continual as opposed to stop/start has also seen a rise to the highest level since February 2011 and the fact that demand has increased from across the world allows some insulation from individual market shocks.

9.57am BST

Greek PMI shows slump continued

I failed to mention Greeece's manufacturing PMI earlier. It came in at 45.4, up from May's 45.3, and its highest level in almost two years. It still shows a deep contraction, though – just less severe than in previous months.

And while new orders and employment levels fell at smaller rates, production levels dropped by more than in May. Hardly a shock, given the economy is still shrinking.

9.41am BST

UK manufacturing output jumps

Britain's factor sector also enjoyed a decent June, posting its strongest growth in more than two years.

Markit's UK manufacturing PMI jumped to 52.5 last month, showing stronger growth following May's 51.5. The data showed a rise in new business, with increased orders from within the UK and abroad.

Markit said the data showed that the UK economy was picking up pace (no wonder Mark Carney had a smile on his face this morning...). GDP probably grew by around 0.5% in the last three months, it said.

David Noble, chief executive at the Chartered Institute of Purchasing & Supply, said momentum was building in the manufacturing sector, although this hadn't fed through to the jobs market yet:

The industry experienced another good month to round off a solid Q2.

Employment is the one disappointing spot, showing little change from last month; a reminder of the anxiety that still exists in the sector.

9.33am BST

Italian unemployment rate hits new record high

A reminder that Italy's economy is still strugging – the seasonally-adjusted jobless rate has hit a new record high of 12.2% in May.

It's the highest rate since records began in 1977, up from 12.0% in April.

And Italy's employment rate remained anemically low at just 56% (showing that little over half the adult population is actually in the labour market).

The youth unemployment rate fell a little, though, to 38.5% from 39.9% the previous month.

At 10am BST we get the overall jobless figure for the eurozone.

9.27am BST

Instant reaction to those PMIs

So in summary, today's manufacturing data has given us reasons for optimism in Italy (9.00am), Spain (8.39am) and France (9.04am), but raised concerns over Germany (9.09am) and China (7.45am).

That suggests that the eurozone slump is easing, at a time when stronger economies are finding conditions rather tougher.

We should applaud any signs that firms in the periphery are managing to drag themselves, and their economies, out of the mire.

And as Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight explained:

The hope for manufacturers is that gradually rising confidence encourages businesses to invest more, and encourages consumers to spend a little more.

Meanwhile, muted input prices are helping Eurozone manufacturers to price competitively.

Hold the schadenfreude, though. Despite a tough June, German factories remain in much better shape than Southern European countries who managed to survive the recession.

And once the eurozone does emerge from its slump, Germany's Mittelstand of small and medium-sized firms will be poised to benefit.

9.09am BST

Germany does worse

... but Germany's factory output fell in June, in the one obvious disappointment amid this morning's encouraging data. German manufacturing PMI fell to 48.6, from May's 49.4 - which means a deeper downturn.

Markit blamed the downturn on falling orders, with economist Mark Wingham commenting:

The German manufacturing sector appears to have remained in the doldrums in June, with a renewed drop in new orders acting as a drag on output growth.

9.04am BST

France does better

Today's splurge of PMI data also offered respite for France, with activity shrinking at the slowest rate in 16 months. Its PMI rose to 48.4, up from 46.4 in May. Still a contraction, but at a slower rate....

Updated at 9.18am BST

9.00am BST

Surprise rise in Italian manufacturing output

Italy's manufacturing PMI has also beaten expectations by hitting its highest level since July 2011, hot on the heels of Spain's own decent performance.

At 49.1, the Italian PMI beat forecasts and showed that the sector enjoyed a less troubled time in June. Although that still shows falling activity, it's a a much stronger reading than May's 47.3.

Markit said the last three months had ended 'positively for the Italian
manufacturing sector', with firms actually producing a higher output than in May.

As with Spain (see 8.39am), Italy benefitted from higher exports.

Phil Smith, economist at Markit, warned that the situation was fragile:

The headline index’s latest rise was largely due to a return to growth in output from a solid rate of decline seen in May.

The upturn won’t be sustained, however, unless we also see the level of new orders in the sector rising in coming months.

8.49am BST

Mark Carney takes control at the BoE

Meanwhile, in London, the new governor of the Bank of England has got down to business.

Mark Carney turned up to work looking undaunted by the task at hand.

I'm prepared to wager my last euro that he'll look less tanned and relaxed when his term ends in 2018, after five years of British weather and monetary policy.

8.39am BST

Spanish manufacturing PMI shows reasons for optimism

Spain's manufacturing sector has finally stopped deteriorating, according to data just released that could bring some much-needed relief to Madrid.

Markit, the data firm, reported that the Spanish PMI came in at exactly 50.0. That's the best result since April 2011, before the Spanish economy entered its current long, deep recession.

New orders increased, and unemployment fell at a slower rate, dragging the PMI up from last month's 48.1.

The graph shows how Spain's factories barely struggled out of the post-Lehman Brothers slump, before entering a new downturn:

One month's PMI data doesn't make a summer, but Markit is optimistic that the decline in the Spanish manufacturing sector is coming to an end.

Markit economist Andrew Harker explained that Spain was benefitting from exports rather than local demand:

The second quarter of 2013 ended on an encouraging note for the Spanish manufacturing sector, with PMI data pointing to a rise in new business and an easing in the rate of decline in production.

The improved performance was heavily reliant on export growth, however, with little sign of recovery in domestic client demand.

It's a stronger performance than economists had expected, as Frederik Ducrozet explains:

Updated at 8.44am BST

8.23am BST

Could Troika demand new measures?

Greece's Kathimerini newspaper reports that the Troika may try to impose new austerity measures on the Greek government when they meet this afternoon (see 8.16am).

It has got its hands on a draft memorandum which suggests further cuts may be demanded, if Antonis Samaras's government doesn't fix a black hole in Greece's funding.

It reports:

According to the draft document, unspecified new measures may have to be taken if authorities fail to collect adequate revenue from outstanding debts to the state and fail to plug a funding gap for this year of just over €1bn, chiefly attributed to the debts of the country’s main healthcare provider, EOPYY.

One potential method of narrowing the funding gap likely to be proposed by troika officials is the payment of the emergency property tax for 2013 in four instalments rather than five. Such a move would narrow the funding gap for this year by an estimated €400m, troika officials are expected to argue.

Kathimerini also reports that Greece's new administrative reform minister, Kyriakos Mitsotakis, will seek a two-month extension in which to select 12,500 civil servants who will be moved into a mobility scheme, in which the employees will receive a reduced wage for a year before a status review.

More here: Troika due back in Athens, with mixed agenda

Updated at 8.26am BST

8.16am BST

Troika back in Athens

The eurozone crisis has been punctuated by regular meetings between officials from the Troika (the International Monetary Fund, European Central Bank and European Commission) and one government or another.

And today it's Greece's turn, as officials from Greece's lenders return to Athens to complete their assessment of its economy.

Finance minister Yannis Stournaras is due to sit down with the Troika at 5pm local time (3pm BST), after a two-week break (officials excused themselves from Greece as the row over closing its state broadcaster, EPA, broke out). At issue, whether Greece has done enough to receive its next bailout tranche, worth €8.1bn.

The government hopes for a slightly easier ride:

The lenders will give us trouble but less so than in previous reviews.

But there are two obvious stumbling blocks:

1) Greece's privatisation programme, which is behind schedule after the failure to sell its gas network DEPA (more here), and dogged by rumours of problems over the sale of gambling form OPAP (more here).

2) Civil service layoffs. The troika wants tens of thousands of public workers cut from the payroll. The government has been flagging on this issue (although shutting EPA will help).

There's speculation that the troika might only hand over a portion of the €8.1bn on the table.

Reuters reports:

To pressure Athens to deliver on reforms, the trio of lenders might refuse to pay the full sum in one go and break it up into three monthly payments instead, Greek media reported.

"The biggest issue in the negotiations will be the delays in public sector reforms," a senior finance ministry official told Reuters.

7.45am BST

Big day for data begins in China

Good morning and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest events in the eurozone, the financial markets and the global economy.

It's a busy day for economic data, with surveys from Beijing to Berlin throwing new light on the state of the global economy. That includes the latest eurozone jobless data (at 10am BST).

While in Greece, officials from its Troika of lenders are due back in Athens for another round of talks over its bailout programme (more on this shortly).

Already in – fresh evidence that China's factories struggled in June.

A monthly assessment of Chinese factory output conducted by HSBC bank, and an official government report, both showed that manufacturers were suffering from falling demand from overseas, and at home. That will reinforce fears over an economic slowdown in China, and underlines that the world economy remains a tough environment.

HSBC's PMI survey fell to a nine-month low of 48.2, which indicates that the sector contracted, while the government's own survey came in at 50.1 – showing virtually no growth, and a hefty fall on May's 50.8.

Analysts are downbeat about prospects in China.

Haibin Zhu, chief China economist of JPMorgan in Hong Kong, said:

The Chinese economy is still struggling at the bottom.

While Xianfang Ren, an economist at IHS, was no more positive, saying:

The Chinese economy is far from out of the woods yet.

With China cracking down on its shadow banking sector, any signs of rapid cooling in its economy will be a concern.

Is Europe coping any better? We'll find out in the next few hours, with new surveys of manufacturing output from across the eurozone.

And then, new jobless data which will show if Europe's unemployment crisis, particularly among the young, has worsened.

I'll be tracking all the action through the day.

Updated at 8.16am BST
fields.bodyText: Time to wrap up for the day. Here's a brief closing summary. • Greece's government has begun a new round of crucial talks with officials fom its lenders. At issue, whether to advance the country's next aid tranche, worth around €8bn. Insiders warned tonight that tension between the two sides is high, as the Troika probes whether Greece has made enough progress cutting civil service staff levels, and selling state assets. Latest analysis from Helena Smith in Athens is here: • Portugal's finance minister has resigned. Vitor Gaspar blamed falling public support for the country's austerity programme, and warned that the Lisbon government faced a difficult future (see 5.03pm onwards). • Eurozone unemployment levels hit new record highs, with the jobless rate rising to 12.1%. The latest figures from Eurostat showed that Spain, Greece and Portugal still have the highest unemployment rates, particularly for young people, while Cyprus's labour market has deteriorated sharply (see 10.14am onwards). • The latest factory data offered some respite for southern Europe. Spain and Italy both posted better-than expected manufacturing PMI figures (see 8.39am onwards. However Germany and China (see 7.45am)'s PMI data missed forecasts, while the US version (see 3.06pm) showed a weakening labour market. • In the UK, Mark Carney took control at the Bank of England. There's video of Carney's first day here (3.22pm), and details of his trip on the Underground here (11.33am). I"ll be back tomorrow. Until then, thanks and goodnight. With those crunch talks between the Greek finance ministry and the Troika underway, our Athens correspondent Helena Smith reports that the situation is as tense as ever. She also flags up that Greec is very likely to only receive its next aid tranche in slices, rather than one lump sum. Here's Helena's analysls: Even when they look good, Greece’s relations with the international creditors keeping its debt-stricken economy afloat are rarely without tension. Both sides regard the other with thinly disguised suspicion. Since troika officials from the EU, ECB and IMF began visiting Athens to pour over the nation’s financial book-keeping, inspection tours have been fraught with friction in a game that, more often than not, resembles a match of constant goal-post moving than one adhered to with fixed rules. Today’s visit is no different. While ties have generally improved in the year since the smooth-talking technocrat Yiannis Stournaras was elevated to the post of finance minister, this afternoon’s discussions are genuinely expected to be “very tough.” The troika has made clear that it will only disburse aid when, and if, specific reforms are taken. The likelihood of the country’s super tranche – €8.1bn in aid – being dispatched in installments is now a given. “It’s going to make for a very heavy climate but they have made it very clear that that is what they are going to do,” said one insider. “Every time we announce a measure, we’ll get an installment. That is the premise they are working on.” Measures now mean pubic sector dismissals – the red line no Greek government has wanted to cross since the outbreak of the debt crisis in late 2009. The troika wants 15,000 civil servants cut from the payroll in 2015. The government missed yesterday’s deadline of placing some 12,500 in a mobility scheme and the Administrative Reform Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis said he would ask for a two-month extension when he met troika mission heads at 7:30pm (local time) (5.30pm BST) tonight. This is unlikely to go down well. Before the fraca over the closure of state broadcaster ERT – one that the government will surely use to highlight the sensitivity of public sector sackings -- troika officials were demanding names and numbers and are going to be reluctant to move the goal posts again. If they do, there will have to be concessions elsewhere – most likely in the reining in of public spending at Greece’s main healthcare provider, EOPYY. The projected financing gap of €4bn by the second half of 2014 (when Greece’s second bailout programme is due to end) has added to the black mood. So has the slow pace of privatisations with officials on both sides now openly recognising the impossibility of raising €2.6bn through the sale of state assets by the end of the year. The atmosphere will worsen considerably if the €700m euro sale of the state lottery company OPAP also falls through. Speculation of this happening has exacerbated tensions with creditors in recent days. Its collapse would automatically increase the need for further cuts to put the bailout programme on track. The health ministry, with EOPYY at the fore, is likely to be called on to carry most of the burden of covering the looming budget gap. The new health minister, Adonis Georgiades, was appointed to the post precisely because he has no ties with the medical community thus making it easier for him to wield the axe. On Sunday evening he lived up to expectation promising he will close hospitals to meet targets “if necessary”. It will be the beginning of the new measures the government is so vehemently insisting it will not take when everything suggests that new measures are in the offing. Reuters is now reporting that Vitor Gaspar blamed his resignation on eroding public support for Portugal's austerity programme, and the court ruling earlier this year that blocked planned cuts to payments for pensioners and public workers. The outgoing finance minister also warned that the "risks and challenges ahead are enormous", and admitted his credibility had been damaged by Portugal's struggle to hit its deficit targets. It's official -- the Portuguese president has confirmed that Vitor Gaspar has stepped down as finance minister, to be replaced by treasury secretary Maria Luis de Albuquerque. Here's the statement from the presidency . And here's a rough translation: Pursuant to paragraph h) of Article 133 of the Constitution, the President accepted the proposal made by the Prime Minister, to dismiss, at his request, the Minister of State and Finance, Prof.. Dr. Vítor Gaspar Louçã Rabaça. The President accepted the proposal made by the Prime Minister, the appointment of Dr. Luis Maria Casanova Morgado Dias de Albuquerque to the same office. The inauguration of the new member of the Government shall take place tomorrow, Tuesday, July 2, at 17:00 in the Palace of Belém. Reuters is now reporting that the Portuguese prime minister has accepted the resignation of Vitor Gaspar as finance minister (so the rumours were true....) He's been replaced by Maria Luis Albuquerque, previously the Treasury secretary. Portugal's finance minister, Vítor Gaspar, may be throwing in the towel, with local media reporting tonight that he is considering tendering his resignation. There's nothing official, so treat with all caution. Gaspar has ploughed a tough furrow in Portugal, trying to implement spending cuts and tax rises demanded by the Troika, in the face of public anger. Peter Spiegel of the FT reports that Gaspar would be missed in Brussels: Europe's stock markets have begun the second half of 2013 with solid gains, led by Spain, Italy and the UK – where the FTSE 100 closed up 92 points. All three countries posted better-than-expected manufacturing data this morning, and this seems to have fed through to traders. Here's the closing prices: Steve Collins, global head of dealing at London & Capital Asset Management, confirmed that the decent manufacturing data had dampened concerns over the situation in Greece. Another curious story involving Greece today: Japonica, a little-known US investment firm, has reduced the price at which it is prepared to buy Greek debt, but is keen to snaffle even more of the stuff. Japonica, of Rhode Island, caused a stir last month when it first proposed buying €2.9bn of Greek debt from existing creditors at 45% of its face value. Today, though, the company announced it will only pay 40 euro cents in the €1. It blamed recent declines in the value of Greek debt, uncertainty over whether it will get its aid tranche, and tension within its government. Or in Japonica's words, the threat of: prospective debt haircuts, Greece government intracoalition relations, reports of a potential €3bn to €4bn funding gap, privatization revenue shortfalls, reports of a €1.2bn health-care-cost funding gap, the closure [of state broadcaster ERT], and concerns regarding quarter-end portfolio performance markings for such illiquid securities. If Greece is in such a mess, you'd think Japonica would keep away. But the firm says it hasn't lost its appetite for Greek debt -- and is now prepared to buy €4bn-worth of bonds. The offer perplexed many in the City, and it's not clear whether anyone's taken up the offer. Greek debt had strengthened steadily since the drama of its two elections in 2012 - so anyone who bought bonds then is sitting on healthy profits. As Bloomberg argues here, they may not want to sell out to Japonica just yet.... Speaking of Greece, its government appears poised to pay €540m to a 'holdout' investor who didn't take part in last year's debt restructuring. The bond, which was issued under Swiss law, matures on Friday. Its owner refused to swap the debt for new, longer-maturity securities in March 2012. And Athens appears to have decided it's better to pay the debt off than refuse to honour it and provoke a legal battle. But while Greece seemingly has the money to settle with holdout creditors, it is still gunning for public services. Health minister Adonis Georgiadis caused alarm over the weekend by saying he was prepared to shut hospitals if it would drive up efficiency and cut costs. And bus drivers are up in arms over a plan to make passengers get on through the front doors, near their cabin, in an effort to stop fare-dodging. The talks between Troika officials and Greek finance minister Yannis Stournaras over the country's bailout programme, and whether Athens should get its next aid tranche worth €8bn, are underway. Here's a photo of European Commission director Matthias Mors, centre, arriving for the meeting this afternoon: With government insiders already warning that the talks will be tough (see 2.12pm onwards) we could be in for a nervy few days.... Your chance to watch a rather powerful central banker walk down a corridor, open a door, and address the massed ranks of the Bank of England's senior staff: Carney appeared to be enjoying the attention, and didn't waste any time telling staff that he'd been there since 7am*. * - not bad for a newcomer. Reminder: I rounded up some of the reams of advice sent Carney's way at 1.10pm The news that hiring across America's manufacturing sector weakened last month (see 3.06pm) drove shares in London and Wall Street even higher (FTSE 100 now up 96 points, Dow up 166 points). Looks like we're back to bad news being good news, if it keeps the ultra-loose monetary policy in place.... The ISM survey of America's manufacturing sector is out (not to be confused with the Markit version released earlier), and it's a mixed picture. The headline figures has improved, rising to 50.9 (denoting growth), following last month's 49.0 (which showed a contraction). However, the 'employment index' part of the survey fell below the 50-point mark for the first time since September 2009, indicating a drop in hiring. And with the Federal Reserve targeting the labour market as well as headline GDP, that may also encourage central bankers to hold off tapering their bond-buying programmes.... The better-than-expected manufacturing data from Italy and Spain (hinting at eurozone recovery), and the weaker-than-expected manufacturing data from America (hinting at a slower end to the US stimulus package) have helped to push shares up today. Wall Street has opened higher, while in London the blue-chip Footsie is up 82 points, mirroring similar gains across Europe. • Dow Jones: up 114 points at 15025, +0.78% • FTSE 100: up 82 points at 6297, + 1.3% • German DAX: up 40 points at 799, + 0.5% • French CAC: up 30 points at 3769, +0.8% • Spanish IBEX: up 140 points at 7903, +1.8% • Italian FTSE MIB: up 261 point at 15501, +1.7% Back to economic data, and the first of two readings of the US manufacturing sector has been released, and is weaker than expected. Markit's PMI survey of America's factory sector last month came in at 51.9, which is the slowest pace of expansion in eight months. The data did show a small rise in business conditions, and output growth, but it suggests the US economy isn't recovering as fast as some analysts had hoped. And that may mean the Federal Reserve doesn't slow its stimulus package so quicky. Chris Williamson, Markit's chief economist, warned that: Manufacturing clearly down-shifted a gear between the first and second quarters, and is at risk of losing further momentum as we head into the second half of the year We get the rival ISM manufacturing data at 3pm BST. In the meantime, European shares are pushing higher - with the FTSE 100 up over 1%. Full round-up to follow As flagged up this morning, one of the key issues on the table in Greece is the planned dismissal of 15,000 civil servants by the end of 2014 and the placing of another 12,500 in a mobility scheme. Kathimerini has more details on this afternoon's talks between Greece and the Troika, pointing out that the meetings will run into tomorrow.... The troika is to begin its meetings at the Finance Ministry on Monday afternoon at 5 pm (3pm BST). They are due to meet new Administrative Reform Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis at 7.30p.m [5.30pm BST]. Mitsotakis is expected to ask for more time to complete the mobility scheme. The inspectors will then visit the Labor Ministry on Tuesday morning. Over in Greece, we're still expecting talks between the government and officials from its lenders to resume this afternoon, around 3pm BST. As outlined this morning (8.23am) the Troika are back in town to see how the Greek government measures up against its bailout targets. And the mood music from Athens isn't encouraging, with one finance ministry official describing the negotiations between Greece and the troika as "truly difficult". A couple of newswires are also quoting unnamed eurozone officials warning that Greece hasn't yet done enough to qualify for its next aid tranche: The improvements in Italy and Spain's manufacturing sectors (see 8.39am onwards) have been welcomed in the City, while the latest eurozone unemployment gloom (10.14am) has been shrugged off. Spanish and Italian government bonds have strengthened in value, pushing their borrowing costs down. The yield (interest rate) on a Spanish 10-year sovereign bond has now fallen to 4.628%, down from 4.71% on Friday night. The Italian equivalent dropped to 4.49% (from 4.53%). Both countries' bonds had fallen in value since the US Federal Reserve laid out how to slow, and stop its stimulus package amost two weeks ago. With several Fed officials having made soothing noises since, traders may reckon there's less to worry about - and that peripheral eurozone debt looks safer again... A couple more photos of Mark Carney's first morning at the Bank of England: The new governor hits the ground running with his first meeting of the monetary policy committee this week (where interest rates and quantitative easing programmes are set). But what should his priorities be? Saturday's Guardian leader column urged Carney to get to grips with Britain's banks, and use every lever he can find to drive growth: The new governor has already hinted that he would like a more flexible inflation target (perhaps keeping CPI to 2% over three not two years); he should go further and push for a Federal Reserve-style remit that sets off moderate inflation against the need for jobs (and wage) growth. Now is also the time to use QE, that is public money, to direct investment into key sectors (such as green energy) and under-industrialised regions. Mr Carney is famously smooth, but if he does not start his tenure by picking a few important fights, it will be a disappointing omen. While five experts have given the Observer their views on the challenges facing Carney -- from weaning Britain off ultra-loose monetary policy to improving the Bank's own credibilty. Here's the details: A little advice, Mr Carney … your credibility will be crucial While the British Chamber of Commerce has called for more help for small firms. And you can vote here on whether Carney will do better than Sir Mervyn King. Over in Cyprus, the finance ministry reports that it has completed a bond-swap with investors, fulfilling another condition of its bailout deal: From the Reuters terminal: Cyprus said on Monday it had completed the exchange of €1bn in maturing domestic government debt for new longer-term government paper as part of its financial adjustment programme. Five types of bonds with maturities ranging from six to 10 years were issued, offering the same coupons as the government bonds they replaced, term sheets issued by the finance ministry said. This swap helps Cyprus as it reduces the amount of sovereign debt it must repay during the lifespan of its bailout programme. But the exchange also saw its credit rating cut to selective default by S&P last Friday (as the new terms are less favourable) Back to London, and my colleague Jennifer Rankin has established that Mark Carney braved the Underground on his first day at the Bank of England this morning. She writes that governor Carney was spotted by at least one City worker, who was able to point him in the right direction: The Canadian central banker is tipped to shake up the 319-year old institution, which has been criticised by politicians for insularity and group-think and not enough vigilance in the runup to the financial crisis. This change of style also starts – today at least – with a journey on the central line, stuffy on a midsummer morning, although he did at least get a seat. "It is nice to see someone being suitably parsimonious," said Justin Urquhart Stewart, managing director of Seven Investment Management, who spotted Carney on the tube. "I've established he definitely wasn't George Clooney," he said. "I wished him good luck." Urquhart Stewart also advised Carney on the best exit to take at Bank underground station. If only all Carney's dilemmas were so easily solved.... More here: Mark Carney takes tube to office on first day as Bank of England governor City analysts believe the eurozone unemployment rate will keep rising in the months ahead, after hitting 12.1% in May (see 10.14am onwards for details). Martin van Vliet of ING explains: The country breakdown showed that the increase in unemployment was broadly-based, with Cyprus again standing out negatively (16.3% versus 15.8% previously) but Germany and Austria bucking the trend of increased unemployment. Looking ahead, an end to the Eurozone labour market downturn is not yet imminent. Indeed, the employment expectations indices from the European Commission’s business survey are still at levels consistent with further increases in unemployment. However, with the recession across the Eurozone petering out, the peak in unemployment should not be too far away either. While Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight has predicted that the rate will hit 12.5% by the end of this year, despite today's encouraging manufacturing PMIs (see 9.27am). Archer writes: A general turnaround in Eurozone labour markets still looks some way off so unemployment seems set to rise appreciably further. The situation will likely vary markedly between countries. While, Eurozone GDP could have finally stopped contracting in the second quarter after a record six quarters of decline, overall economic activity is likely to remain too weak through 2013, and very possibly during the early months of 2014, to prevent unemployment from rising further. The cost of living in the eurozone picked up late last month, but at 1.6% the consumer prices index remained low in historical terms. Eurostat said the increase in the CPI, from 1.4% last month, was due to increased costs of food, alcohol and tobacco, energy, and services. The European Central Bank's aim is to keep inflation close to, but below, 2%, so today's reading shouldn't alarm policymakers, and might even calm fears of deflation. Although, as Mario Draghi explained at his most recent press conference on June 6: The fact that inflation is low is not, by itself, bad; with low inflation, you can buy more stuff. Nice to see an economist cutting through the jargon.... Last week, European leaders were proudly announcing that they'd put €8bn aside to fight youth unemployment. Today's data confirms that the problem is particularly severe in southern Europe. Greece is suffering a youth unemployment rate of 59.2%, followed by Spain with 56.5% and Portugal with 42.1%. Northern European countries are in much better shape, particularly Germany (7.6%), Austria (8.7%) and the Netherlands (10.6%). Eurostat has calculated that there are 3.531m young people out of work in the eurozone, up by 60,000 on a year ago, and 5.5m across the Euopean Union. The only upside? Eurostat has revised its historical data down, so that the youth jobless rate is 23.8% across the eurozone (not the 24.4% estimated last month). And while the eurozone jobless rate hit a new record high, the rate in the European Union was flat in May, at 10.9%. That's because the proportion of people out of work in some EU countries outside the euro fell, including Sweden (from 8.3% to 7.9), and Denmark (from 5.4% to 5.3%). Seventeen members of the eurozone have higher unemployment rates than a year ago, and 10 have lower rates -- which pushed the jobless rate up to today's 12.1% in May. Once again, the lowest unemployment rates were recorded in Austria (4.7%), Germany (5.3%) and Luxembourg (5.7%), and the highest in Spain (26.9%) and Greece (26.8% in March 2013). Cyprus, which was dragged into a bailout crisis earlier this month, suffered the biggest annual rise - from 11.4% in May 2012 to 16.3% this year. Greece's jobless rate rose from 22.2% to 26.8% over the last year. And Slovenia, which is fighting to avoid taking a bailout, has seen its jobless rate increase from 8.6% a year ago to 11.2% today. The largest decreases were observed in Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania. The unemployment rate across the eurozone hit record levels in May, as the recession continued to hurt workers across the region. Eurostat reported that the jobless rate across the eurozone was 12.1% in May, up from 12.0% in April. It was driven by increased unemployment rates in countries at the heart of the crisis, including Spain, Italy, and Ireland. The number of people out of work across the eurozone rose by 67,000, and picked up by 16,000 in the wider European Union. And young people continued to find themselves in the front line of the jobless crisis -- the youth unemployment rate was 23.0% in the EU27 and 23.8% in the euro area, up from 22.8% and 23.0% respectively a year ago. There are now 26.405m unemployed men and women in the EU27, of whom 19.222 million were in the euro area. The only reason for optimism is that Eurostat has revised down its earlier data slightly-- it had previously estimated the eurozone jobless rate at 12.2% in May. That's small comfort, though. Details and reaction to follow.... Jeremy Cook of World First says the City was cheered by the news that Britain's manufacturing sector enjoyed its best month in two years (see 9.41am) Sterling and gilts are higher after the announcement which is a nice welcoming present for the new Bank of England Governor, Mark Carney, on his first day in the job…” The new orders component which tends to suggest that demand should be continual as opposed to stop/start has also seen a rise to the highest level since February 2011 and the fact that demand has increased from across the world allows some insulation from individual market shocks. I failed to mention Greeece's manufacturing PMI earlier. It came in at 45.4, up from May's 45.3, and its highest level in almost two years. It still shows a deep contraction, though – just less severe than in previous months. And while new orders and employment levels fell at smaller rates, production levels dropped by more than in May. Hardly a shock, given the economy is still shrinking. Britain's factor sector also enjoyed a decent June, posting its strongest growth in more than two years. Markit's UK manufacturing PMI jumped to 52.5 last month, showing stronger growth following May's 51.5. The data showed a rise in new business, with increased orders from within the UK and abroad. Markit said the data showed that the UK economy was picking up pace (no wonder Mark Carney had a smile on his face this morning...). GDP probably grew by around 0.5% in the last three months, it said. David Noble, chief executive at the Chartered Institute of Purchasing & Supply, said momentum was building in the manufacturing sector, although this hadn't fed through to the jobs market yet: The industry experienced another good month to round off a solid Q2. Employment is the one disappointing spot, showing little change from last month; a reminder of the anxiety that still exists in the sector. A reminder that Italy's economy is still strugging – the seasonally-adjusted jobless rate has hit a new record high of 12.2% in May. It's the highest rate since records began in 1977, up from 12.0% in April. And Italy's employment rate remained anemically low at just 56% (showing that little over half the adult population is actually in the labour market). The youth unemployment rate fell a little, though, to 38.5% from 39.9% the previous month. At 10am BST we get the overall jobless figure for the eurozone. So in summary, today's manufacturing data has given us reasons for optimism in Italy (9.00am), Spain (8.39am) and France (9.04am), but raised concerns over Germany (9.09am) and China (7.45am). That suggests that the eurozone slump is easing, at a time when stronger economies are finding conditions rather tougher. We should applaud any signs that firms in the periphery are managing to drag themselves, and their economies, out of the mire. And as Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight explained: The hope for manufacturers is that gradually rising confidence encourages businesses to invest more, and encourages consumers to spend a little more. Meanwhile, muted input prices are helping Eurozone manufacturers to price competitively. Hold the schadenfreude, though. Despite a tough June, German factories remain in much better shape than Southern European countries who managed to survive the recession. And once the eurozone does emerge from its slump, Germany's Mittelstand of small and medium-sized firms will be poised to benefit. ... but Germany's factory output fell in June, in the one obvious disappointment amid this morning's encouraging data. German manufacturing PMI fell to 48.6, from May's 49.4 - which means a deeper downturn. Markit blamed the downturn on falling orders, with economist Mark Wingham commenting: The German manufacturing sector appears to have remained in the doldrums in June, with a renewed drop in new orders acting as a drag on output growth. Today's splurge of PMI data also offered respite for France, with activity shrinking at the slowest rate in 16 months. Its PMI rose to 48.4, up from 46.4 in May. Still a contraction, but at a slower rate.... Italy's manufacturing PMI has also beaten expectations by hitting its highest level since July 2011, hot on the heels of Spain's own decent performance. At 49.1, the Italian PMI beat forecasts and showed that the sector enjoyed a less troubled time in June. Although that still shows falling activity, it's a a much stronger reading than May's 47.3. Markit said the last three months had ended 'positively for the Italian manufacturing sector', with firms actually producing a higher output than in May. As with Spain (see 8.39am), Italy benefitted from higher exports. Phil Smith, economist at Markit, warned that the situation was fragile: The headline index’s latest rise was largely due to a return to growth in output from a solid rate of decline seen in May. Meanwhile, in London, the new governor of the Bank of England has got down to business. Mark Carney turned up to work looking undaunted by the task at hand. I'm prepared to wager my last euro that he'll look less tanned and relaxed when his term ends in 2018, after five years of British weather and monetary policy. Markit, the data firm, reported that the Spanish PMI came in at exactly 50.0. That's the best result since April 2011, before the Spanish economy entered its current long, deep recession. New orders increased, and unemployment fell at a slower rate, dragging the PMI up from last month's 48.1. The graph shows how Spain's factories barely struggled out of the post-Lehman Brothers slump, before entering a new downturn: One month's PMI data doesn't make a summer, but Markit is optimistic that the decline in the Spanish manufacturing sector is coming to an end. Markit economist Andrew Harker explained that Spain was benefitting from exports rather than local demand: The second quarter of 2013 ended on an encouraging note for the Spanish manufacturing sector, with PMI data pointing to a rise in new business and an easing in the rate of decline in production. It's a stronger performance than economists had expected, as Frederik Ducrozet explains: Greece's Kathimerini newspaper reports that the Troika may try to impose new austerity measures on the Greek government when they meet this afternoon (see 8.16am). It has got its hands on a draft memorandum which suggests further cuts may be demanded, if Antonis Samaras's government doesn't fix a black hole in Greece's funding. It reports: According to the draft document, unspecified new measures may have to be taken if authorities fail to collect adequate revenue from outstanding debts to the state and fail to plug a funding gap for this year of just over €1bn, chiefly attributed to the debts of the country’s main healthcare provider, EOPYY. One potential method of narrowing the funding gap likely to be proposed by troika officials is the payment of the emergency property tax for 2013 in four instalments rather than five. Such a move would narrow the funding gap for this year by an estimated €400m, troika officials are expected to argue. Kathimerini also reports that Greece's new administrative reform minister, Kyriakos Mitsotakis, will seek a two-month extension in which to select 12,500 civil servants who will be moved into a mobility scheme, in which the employees will receive a reduced wage for a year before a status review. More here: Troika due back in Athens, with mixed agenda The eurozone crisis has been punctuated by regular meetings between officials from the Troika (the International Monetary Fund, European Central Bank and European Commission) and one government or another. And today it's Greece's turn, as officials from Greece's lenders return to Athens to complete their assessment of its economy. Finance minister Yannis Stournaras is due to sit down with the Troika at 5pm local time (3pm BST), after a two-week break (officials excused themselves from Greece as the row over closing its state broadcaster, EPA, broke out). At issue, whether Greece has done enough to receive its next bailout tranche, worth €8.1bn. The government hopes for a slightly easier ride: The lenders will give us trouble but less so than in previous reviews. But there are two obvious stumbling blocks: 1) Greece's privatisation programme, which is behind schedule after the failure to sell its gas network DEPA (more here), and dogged by rumours of problems over the sale of gambling form OPAP (more here). 2) Civil service layoffs. The troika wants tens of thousands of public workers cut from the payroll. The government has been flagging on this issue (although shutting EPA will help). There's speculation that the troika might only hand over a portion of the €8.1bn on the table. Reuters reports: To pressure Athens to deliver on reforms, the trio of lenders might refuse to pay the full sum in one go and break it up into three monthly payments instead, Greek media reported. "The biggest issue in the negotiations will be the delays in public sector reforms," a senior finance ministry official told Reuters. Good morning and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest events in the eurozone, the financial markets and the global economy. It's a busy day for economic data, with surveys from Beijing to Berlin throwing new light on the state of the global economy. That includes the latest eurozone jobless data (at 10am BST). While in Greece, officials from its Troika of lenders are due back in Athens for another round of talks over its bailout programme (more on this shortly). Already in – fresh evidence that China's factories struggled in June. Analysts are downbeat about prospects in China. Haibin Zhu, chief China economist of JPMorgan in Hong Kong, said: The Chinese economy is still struggling at the bottom. While Xianfang Ren, an economist at IHS, was no more positive, saying: The Chinese economy is far from out of the woods yet. With China cracking down on its shadow banking sector, any signs of rapid cooling in its economy will be a concern. Is Europe coping any better? We'll find out in the next few hours, with new surveys of manufacturing output from across the eurozone. And then, new jobless data which will show if Europe's unemployment crisis, particularly among the young, has worsened. I'll be tracking all the action through the day.
fields.headline: Eurozone crisis: Portugal's finance minister resigns, as Greece holds Troika talks - as it happened
fields.trailText: Jobless rate in eurozone hits 12.1% in May, after latest manufacturing data showed that conditions could be easing in Italy and Spain

webTitle: Monitise jumps 4% as mobile payments group unveils Telefonica partnership

fields.standfirst: Company says deal with telecoms group will involve substantial revenues over the next five years
fields.body:
Monitise has jumped 4% after the mobile payment specialist announced it had formed a partnership with Telefonica Digital to develop new services for the telecoms group's customers. Monitise said the five year agreement would involve substantial minimum revenues for the company with the City suggesting it could be worth some $12m a year. Analyst Bob Liao at the company's broker Canaccord Genuity said it was a "game-changing contract":

The contract involves minimum revenues within range of the recently announced partnership with Visa Europe ($60m over three years). Under the agreement, Monitise becomes Telefonica Digital's preferred partner in mobile payments and commerce platforms. The initial focus of the partnership will be the UK but as preferred partner the expectation is that Monitise will be working with Telefonica Digital across other territories.
The contract is Monitise's first major alliance outside the traditional financial institutions. We see it leading to opportunities with other companies in the mobile ecosystem. Today's ground-breaking agreement opens a new market for Monitise. We view Telefonica as an ideal mobile network operators with which to collaborate: it is the world's third-largest mobile operator with 241m mobile subscribers and 316m total subscribers with particular strength in Latin America. Equally important, we believe Telefonica is one of the most dynamic and innovative operators in the mobile money market. The contract strongly underpins 2013 results and our expectations for growth in 2014. We estimate the agreement is one of Monitise's largest annual revenue generators, with opportunities to increase in value over time. We reiterate our buy recommendation and target price of 50p.

Monitise is currently up 1.5p at 36p.

webTitle: EasyJet founder to vote against airline's plan to buy 135 new Airbus planes

fields.standfirst: Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou says he will reject £8bn deal over easyJet's failure to disclose discount it secured from Airbus
fields.body:
EasyJet's founder and largest shareholder, Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou, has said he will vote against the budget airline's plan to buy 135 new aircraft, at an investor meeting later this month.

The company revealed last month that it had agreed to buy 35 current generation A320 aircraft and 100 new generation A320neo aircraft from Airbus, for delivery between 2015 – 2022. It has options to buy a further 100 A320neo planes.

If the deal goes ahead, easyJet will use the new aircraft to replace ageing planes as they leave the fleet, and to facilitate growth.

Haji-Ioannou, who founded the airline in 1995 and owns a 37% stake with his family, said in an open letter to shareholders that he would reject the deal worth around $11.9bn (£8bn) at list prices at the meeting on 11 July.

In his latest clash with the easyJet board, he criticised its failure to disclose the level of discount secured from Airbus, describing it as a secret deal, and asking: "Would you eat in a restaurant where the menu has no prices?"

"As the person with the most to gain if this company increases profitability and the most to lose if the outcome from this order is not as promised by the board, it is my firm opinion that this is a good deal for Airbus and a bad deal for easyJet shareholders," he wrote.

He added: "I strongly believe public company directors should be legally held to account for their decisions. I will hold these directors to account, if at some point in the future it turns out that their decision to overcommit the company today was wrong."

Haji-Ioannou said his objections were partly based on a belief that the new order will lead to a hunt for new, unprofitable routes. He also claimed that costs per seat had increased by 25% over the past four years, arguing that if the trend continued, customers were unlikely to pay the "ever increasing ticket prices".

Despite his objections, Haji-Ioannou said he expected the majority of shareholders to approve the plan.

A spokesman for easyJet declined to comment.

webTitle: Tullow Oil tops FTSE 100 risers as Nomura raises recommendation ahead of update

fields.standfirst: Analysts turn more positive on oil group after recent share price falls and expect positive news on outlook
fields.body:
Tullow Oil has gushed to the top of the FTSE 100 ahead of a trading update on Wednesday.

The company's shares are up 36p or 3.5% to £10.37 following an upgrade from Nomura, which has moved from reduce to neutral. Analyst Theepan Jothilingam said:

With the shares down 40% (in US dollar terms) since last February's high and a number of 'trigger well' results expected in the next few months, we close our short. Wednesday's trading update should be a positive catalyst particularly versus generally lacklustre outlooks for the large-cap majors in Europe. The long-term risk-reward appears more balanced on relative valuation, hence the upgrade to neutral.
[There are] three reasons for our upgrade: 1) Less expensive and lower expectations: The shares now discount around $1.7bn of exploration and appraisal success, which compares to a peak of $4bn over the last 12 months. Expectations have been pared back significantly for French Guiana and Sabissa in Ethiopia while the Mozambique oil play is recognised as high risk. Similarly, contingent values have narrowed for TEN [an oil fields project in Ghana], Uganda and other discoveries in West Africa. 2) The exploration business could re-rate on a 'trigger well': drillbit newsflow across the industry through 2012 and the first half of 2013 has been disappointing. A six pronged campaign testing multiple geological plays suggests Tullow's business remains extremely active and competitive. Flagship drilling in Kenya, French Guiana, Mauritania, and Norway will keep the 'wells to watch' investors busy in the second half. 3) Delivering a disposal strategy: Government approval of the TEN development, alongside a final investment decision in Uganda should accelerate this process. The reference valuations may not be accretive to net asset value, but should convince investors Tullow is moving away from the Big Oil model.

Elsewhere oil services group Hunting is 42p higher at 774p, the biggest riser in the FTSE 250, after an upbeat trading statement showing it was benefiting from increasing business in the Gulf of Mexico and from the US oil shale industry.

But gold producer Centamin is down 0.6p at 30.99p on continuing unrest in Egypt. The company is involved in a dispute over its licence for the Sukari mine in the country, and the current political uncertainty is unlikely to help matters.
